title: 'Adding Security Groups Odoo'
date: 2020-09-06T21:27:04+01:00
draft: true
tags: ['Odoo']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

Odoo apps typically provide two groups, a user level, for use by regular users, and a
manager level, with additional access to app configuration, or you may In the case of Odoo sale Management, the administrator can see all the sales but a salesman can see only his sales.

This security groups also used to control the access to fields and menues

Access-security related files are usually kept in a /security module subdirector

Inside this directory create a file modulename_security.xml

To organize the groups we need to create a category in the category model in odoo database

?xml version="1.0" ?
odoo
    record id="module{modulename}category" model="ir.module.category"
        field name="name"{modulename}/field
    /record
/odoo

Next we need to create a security group caters for regular user, in modulename_security.xml immediately before /odoo

!-- Library User Group --
record id="{moduelname}groupuser" model="res.groups"
field name="name"User/field
field name="categoryid" ref="module{modulename}_category"/
field name="impliedids" eval="[(4, ref('base.groupuser'))]"/
/record

name is the group title.
category_id is the related app. It is a relational field, so the ref attribute is used with an XML ID linking it to the category we've already created.
implied_ids is a one-to-many relational field, and contains a list of groups that
  will also apply to users belonging to this group, to inherit its privileges.

  record id="librarygroupmanager" model="res.groups"
        field name="name"Manager/field
        field name="categoryid" ref="modulelibrary_category"/
        field name="impliedids" eval="[(4, ref('librarygroup_user'))]"/
        <field name="users" eval="[(4, ref('base.user_root')),
(4, ref('base.user_admin'))]"/
    /record

The only difference field users field, it's used set so that the administrator and the internal root users are automatically app managers.

title: "Advantages of Centralized Storage "
date: 2020-10-17T17:25:30+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["hardware", "storage"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
Disk Utilization
 Thin provisioning

Thin provisioning provides a means by which makes the storage appear to the servers that they have more storage than you have paid. 

Using centralized storage allows for thin provisioning; when the storage is getting low,  adding more physical storage is a cinch. The client is oblivious to any change, which shifts your focus from the 'just in case' to 'just in time' model of purchasing storage space.

Deduplication and Compression 
Detect and eliminates identical blocks; those blocks are then replaced with reference to a single copy of the block on disk, so it saves you a lot of space.

On the other hand, compression detects and eliminates redundant data and white space in files.

 Resiliency 

If any component failed there is another component to add as a backup. 

Centralized management 

It's much easier to manage all your storage from a centralized location rather than separately across all your servers.

 Storage Tiering

The system can have a wide range of storage media for different purposes, SSD (caters to hot data), SATA (caters to cold data) ..so on 

Disaster recovery and load balancing
Replicate the data to a disaster recover site.
Allow for load balancing. 

 Virtualization support 
 
One of the virtualization hallmarks is moving virtual servers between physical servers on the fly while they are still running. Using centralized storage unlocks the possibility of virtual machine migration.

---

Bearish Harami

Consists of an unusually large green body followed by a small red body (contained within large green body). It is considered as a bearish pattern when preceded by an uptrend

 Bullish Harami

Consists of an unusually large red body followed by a small green body (contained within large red body). It is considered as a bullish pattern when preceded by a downtrend. Engulfing Bullish Consists of a small red body that is contained within the followed large green candlestick. When it appears at bottom it is interpreted as a major reversal signal.

title: "Centralized Storage"
date: 2020-10-18T14:08:31+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["storage", "hardware", "cloud"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
Before we get into centralized storage, we should touch on the classic storage DAS.

DAS (Direct Attached Storage), is the traditional storage type; as the name itself implies it refers to storage which is dedicated to the use of the computer of server, like this disk integrated in your laptop or PC.   

Centralized storage 
Both SAN and NAS provide shared, centralized storage that many devices can access over a network.

Those type of storage system has its own controller, a.k.a the head; the controller consists of a motherboard, CPU, network. In addition to the controller, the storage system inevitably has disk(s), whether internal or external.

Like your server, the storage system needs an OS as well; the OS lives on top of the controller; what the OS does is lives on the controller and manages communication out to clients and disk subsystem as well, and it controls running all the features like deduplication, compression, and so on.

 So why to use NAS or SAN rather than DAS.

The utilization you always getting is around 30% of disk space of the dedicated hard disks due to overprovisioning and having buffers; on the other hand, centralized storage provides a centralized pool of shared storage, which brings the utilization closer to 80%.

tags: ['Thinking Fallacies']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

Possibility effect

The possibility effect represents the overestimation of very small probabilities. Small probabilities are either ignored or highly overestimated. Small probabilities that are ignored are in essence rare events that you don't even consider or think of. One example is being struck by lightning

 Certainty Effect

The certainty effect is the psychological effect resulting from the reduction of probability from certainty to probable

title: 'Correlation Coefficient'
date: 2020-07-26T12:45:44+01:00
draft: true
tags: ['Statistics']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

Correlation coefficients are used in statistics to measure how strong a relationship is between two variables

Correlation coefficient formulas are used to find how strong a relationship is between data. The formulas return a value between -1 and 1, where:

1 indicates a perfect positive relationship.
-1 indicates a perfect negative relationship.
A result of zero indicates no relationship at all.

A correlation coefficient of 1 means that for every positive increase in one variable, there is a positive increase of a fixed proportion in the other. For example, shoe sizes go up in (almost) perfect correlation with foot length.
A correlation coefficient of -1 means that for every positive increase in one variable, there is a negative decrease of a fixed proportion in the other. For example, the amount of gas in a tank decreases in (almost) perfect correlation with speed.
Zero means that for every increase, there isn’t a positive or negative increase. The two just aren’t related.

title: "CPU Virtualization"
date: 2021-01-13T00:20:43Z
draft: true
tags: ["virtualization"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
In a physical environment, the operating system always assumes the ownership of all physical resources.  In a virtual environment, many, if not most, operating systems are oblivious to the fact that it doesn't actually own those resources; however, sometimes, the operating system is virtualization-aware.

CPU virtualization involves a single CPU acting as if it were multiple separate CPUs.  The most common reason for doing this is to run multiple operating systems on one host, so every operating system has its CPU.

The underlying physical resources are used whenever possible. The virtualization layer runs instructions only as needed to make virtual machines operate as if they were running directly on a physical device.

When many virtual machines are running on an ESXi host, those virtual machines might compete for CPU resources. When CPU contention occurs, the ESXi host time-slices the physical processors across all virtual machines, so each virtual machine runs as if it has its specified number of virtual processors.

The first virtual machine needs to execute a set of commands on the virtual hardware, and that request is directed to the hypervisor.
The hypervisor schedules an execution session for that virtual machine's request.
The physical CPU executes the instructions on the associated data and passes the results back to the hypervisor, which returns them to the first virtual machine.
As the physical CPU frees up, the hypervisor schedules the next set of instructions from the second virtual machine to be performed

Also, virtual CPUs are not mapped to physical CPUs. A hypervisor will schedule work on behalf of a virtual machine on any available physical CPU, so the work from a particular virtual machine might actually be run on any and all of the host processors over a period of time.

What happens when you add vCPUs to virtual machines? If you have a virtual machine with two vCPUs, the hypervisor will need to schedule work on two physical CPUs. That means two physical CPUs would need to be available at the same time for the work to be performed. Don't forget, virtualizing a CPU is really just scheduling slices of time on the physical CPU. In the case of a VM with more than one vCPU, you need more than one physical CPU to be available to do the work.

Limit CPU features exposed to virtual machines. 
You can mask some of the CPU features to not be exposed to the virtual machine; a common example is "AMD No eXecute (NX)" and  "Intel eXecute Disable (XD)". It is considered a common practice when you plan to migrate those virtual machines to hosts that do not include those capabilities.

Direct current. Current flows only one way from a DC source, an example of which is a battery.

title: 'Dataclasses Python'
date: 2020-08-25T21:31:13+01:00
draft: false
tags: ['python']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

In python 3.6 and lower, the typical way to create a class in python with data members would be something like: !--more--

class Book:
 def init(self, title, author, pages, price):
    self.title = title
    self.author = author
    self.pages = pages
    self.price = price

By introducing dataclasses in version 3.7 the code became more concise, if you have an a typescript background, declaration of attributes are analogous to typescript

from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class Book:
    title: str
    author: str
    pages: int
    price: float

b1 = Book("War and Peace", "Leo Tolstoy", 1225, 39.95)

print(b1.description)

So as you see the class with @dataclass, and list the instance attributes with ther data type, In addition to that, it implements eq and repr behind the scene.

post_init

Looking back at the preceding dataclass example, question pop out as to how can we deal with attribute that depends on other attributes?

The answer is using post_init

 def post_init(self):
        self.description = f"{self.title} by {self.author}, {self.pages}"

We can access the new introduced attribute description as below

b1 = Book("War and Peace", "Leo Tolstoy", 1225, 39.95)

print(b1.description)

title: "Esxi vs Vsphere vs Vcenter"
date: 2020-10-16T23:50:30+01:00
draft: true
tags: ["virtualization", "devops", "vmware"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
vSphere
vSphere is the name for VMware’s entire cloud computing virtualization platform (brand name for VMware’s suite of virtualization products and features. ) Its ultimate goal is to let you virtualize and aggregate the resources of the underlying physical hardware, and offer pools of virtual resources to your datacenter.

On the other hand ESXi and vCenter Server are two of the components of vSphere.

ESXi, the hypervisor, is the virtualization layer that runs immediately on physical servers. Its core function is to abstract the resources of the host, such as CPU, memory, and storage capacities, into multiple VM

 vCenter Server 

vCenter Server can be called a point for centralized configuring, provisioning, and managing the virtual infrastructure. The functionality of vCenter Server allows you to control access permissions, monitor performance and set up notifications.

vSphere Client 
To connect remotely to vCenter Server, you can use either vSphere Client or vSphere Web Client. With vSphere Client, you can establish a connection from any Windows-based PC, while vSphere Web Client allows you to access vCenter Server from a browser or other operating systems.

title: 'ETF vs Shares vs MutualFunds'
date: 2020-07-12T15:21:54+01:00
draft: true
tags: ['Stock Market']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

ETF

Stands for Exchange-Traded Fund

The difference between a stock and an ETF is like the difference between a can of soup and a whole grocery store

When you buy a stock you’re investing in a single company — Apple for instance. When that company does well, the stock price goes up and so does the value of your investment. When it goes down? Share is single unit of stock

When you buy an ETF you’re buying a whole collection of different stocks (or bonds, etc.).

But more than that, an ETF is like investing in the market as a whole, rather than trying to pick individual “winners” and “losers.”

 ETF Advantages

There are a few advantages to ETFs, which are the cornerstone of the successful strategy known as passive investing.

One is that you can buy and sell them like a stock.
Another is that they're safer than buying individual stocks

Mutual Fund

---

Just about every breadboard is made of three sections: Two sets of very long power rails and the large middle section that is full of those 5-hole-long terminal strips.

The power rails are long columns used to distribute the power and ground connections along the entire circuit.

The rows have 5 teeth - one for each hole on the top of the breadboard. (The power rails have 50 teeth)

These little teeth are great at gripping onto electronic parts. When a part is pushed into the breadboard, the clip pushes open and grabs onto the metal leg. Any other parts that are plugged into the other 4 teeth are thus electrically connected together

title: "How to Install iOS 13 Beta Profile"
date: 2020-05-20T01:25:56+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["iOS", "mac"]
---

iOS releases a major free update annually in June, that being said it wont be available for public access up till September.

But what if you can't wait to shake the new killer features out?!--more--You still can install a beta version, this tutorial reveals how to get iOS 13 beta installed in minutes.

Install iOS 13 developer beta

There are a couple of different ways you can install the developer beta, eiher over the air, or through iTunes.

 Install iOS 13 developer beta over-the-air

On your iOS device, navigate to the Apple Developer Program website and Log in with your Apple ID.
Go to the Download sections and scroll down to Featured Downloads.
Tap the blue Download icon next to the iOS 13 beta.
Select the correct profile for your device, and install it.
Reboot.
Go to Settings  General  Software Update and download the iOS 13 beta.

Install iOS 13 developer beta via iTunes

Installing iOS 13 developer beta via iTunes is more than a straightforward task:

First, you need to install the latest version of iTunes and Xcode 11 beta on your Mac.
Head on over to Apple's developer site and login in with your Apple ID.
Enroll your Apple device's UDID.
Once you get enrolled, you'll be able to download the beta version of the iOS - select the exact iPhone, iPod touch or iPad model you're using from the list.
Extract the file that downloads to your Mac (this should produce a .IPSW file)
Connect your device to iTunes (if it isn't already) and tap the iOS device icon int he top-left.
Hold the Option key and hit the Restore iPhone button on the device's Summary tab (next to Check for Update).
Select the .IPSW file from the previous step, and tap Open.
The iOS beta will be installed on your iPad or iPhone in a few.

 How to get the public beta

The iOS 13 public beta has now launched. If you area after giving it a whirl, first, you'll need access Apple Beta.

Hit Sign Up on the Apple Beta page and register with your Apple ID.
Sign in to the Beta Software Program.
Click Enrol your iOS device. (If you signed up for a previous version's beta last year you may need to uninstall the profile for that and then re-enrol for the new one.)
Navigate to beta.apple.com/profile on your iOS device.
Download and install the configuration profile.
That will make the beta version available in the Settings app, under General, Software Update.

title: "How to Use Disposable BBQ"
date: 2020-05-27T19:33:11+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["BBQ", "party", "cooking"]
---

This post wants to give you a flavor of how to use disposable grill, but first you should know that there is no significant difference from any other traditional grills.!--more--

The great thing about disposable grills is that they contain everything your BBQ required with an excellent value for money!.

There are wide range of disposable grills in the market but cooking on almost every disposable grill follows the same steps:

Starting off with the obvious, simply remove the outer packaging.
Then, light the corner of the starter sheet and keep it going for about 15 minutes.
Once the charcoal reaches even temperature, and the coals turn grey, the BBQ is good to go.

So what's the catch?

You need to be forewarned of couple of things when dealing with disposable grill

Unlike typical BBQs, disposable grill doesn't not take advantage from an adjustable height, so ensure it’s positioned in a safe place.

Be mindful not to keep any flames before moving on with cooking as that could lead to a burnt outside raw inside dish.

 Do disposable grills give the same flavour as regular ones

If you think you disposable BBQ can’t give the same BBQ flavour, think again! Remember that the secret is in the sizzle - heated food releases fat that drips onto the charcoal and creates the smoke that makes your BBQ food tastes so good.

How long disposable grills remain hot

Disposable grills tend to stay hot enough for BBQ for 1.5 hours thereafter ignition.

 Disposing the disposable grill

Once you’re done with BBQ is over, you need to put out them safely.

Either Sand or water will be fine for this purpose, always protecting your hands. Once extinguished, leave the BBQ to cool down completely before dumping it safely. these types of grill are not designed for recycling so don’t throw them into the recycling bin.

title: "Jumper Wires"
date: 2020-07-10T20:14:45+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["Raspberry Pi"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
Jumper wires are as simple as the name suggests; they are wires that end with pins, enabling them to connect two points without having a lot of soldering overhead. Jumper wires are conventionally used with breadboards and other prototyping tools to make changes to the circuit as a joy. !--more--

What Do the Colors Mean?

Albeit jumper wires come in many colors, colors have no special meaning. A red jumper wire is not dissimilar to a black one.  The colors work to your advantage, though, different types of connections, such as ground or power.

 Types of Jumper Wires

Jumper wires typically all into three configurations:

male to female
male to male (most common)
female to female.

The difference between each is in the endpoint of the wire. Male ends have a pin protruding and can plug into things, while female ends do not and are used to plug things into. Male-to-male jumper wires are ubiquitous and what you likely will use most often. When connecting two ports on a breadboard, a male-to-male wire is what you’ll need.

title: "Pub Sub vs Message Queue"
date: 2020-05-26T01:04:32+01:00
draft: true
tags: ["architecture"]
---

Message Queue should not to be confused with publish-subscribe, this post attempts to give you a high-level distinction between the two ubiquitous messaging approaches

Message Queue

In message Queue only one single consumer will receive each message on the topic. Which consumer receives which message is dictated by the implementation of the message queue.

To ensure that a message is only processed by one consumer, each message is removed from the queue upon receiving and processing by a consumer (for instance once a consumer has acknowledged consumption of the message to the messaging system).

 Pub Sub

However, in contrast to message queuing, publish-subscribe messaging allows multiple consumers to receive each message in a topic.

x, y= 10, 100

Code block

To distinguish code blocks, PHP like any classic programming language depends on braces, more precisely, curly braces, that's not case when it comes to python, python hinges on indention.

i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i + = 1

 Conditional

There is no significant difference between python and php in terms of conditional, may be the only subtle difference of elif in python is the equivalent of else if in php.

Expression can precede condition

Python doesn't support same ternary operator not exactly but not far off being concise

a if condition else b

st = "x is less than y" if  (x<y) else "x is greater than or the same as y"

 Loop

 while(x < 5):
    print(x)
    x = x+1

Python doesn't have do-while loop, it supports only while and for loop, speaking of for loop, python doesn't have the traditional form of for loop for(x = 0 ; x  5 ; x++), there is no loop counter like you see in javascript, for in python is iterative

for x in range(5,10)
    print(x)

However if you have a use case that requires a counter, the enumerate() function lend itself to this purpose, as it adds a counter to the iterable and returns it in a form of enumerate object.

days = ["MON", "TUE", "WED", "THU", "FRI"]
    for i, d in enumerate(days):
        print(i, d)

The output will be

0 MON
1 TUE
2 WED
3 THU
4 FRI

Function in python vs php

Function is defined by the keyword 'def' in python whereas it's function in php

 Splat operator

This feature allows you to capture a variable number of arguments to a function

function calc($currency, ...$rates) {
    foreach($rate in $rates) {
        print(currency * rate)
    }
}

in php we use the ..., the equivalent inn python is \*

def calc(currency, *rates):
    for rate in rates:
        print(currency * rate)
def main():
    calc(20, 2)
    calc(20, 2, 3)
    calc(20, 2, 3, 4)

Named parameters

Unlike php python supports name parameters, so called keyword parameters

def my_function(child3, child2, child1):
  print("The youngest child is " + child3)

 my_function(child1 = "Tobias", child3 = "Linus", child2 = "Emil")

Notice that, the order doesn't matter as long as you call out all of the parameters

title: 'Regression to the Mean'
date: 2020-07-26T12:35:10+01:00
draft: false
tags: ['Statistics']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

Regression toward (or to) the mean is the phenomenon that arises if a sample of a random variable is extreme, a future sample will be closer to the mean or average on further measurements !--more--

Why Does Regression to the Mean Happen?

Regression to the mean tend to happens due to sampling error. A proper sampling method is to randomly sample from the population. If you don’t (i.e. if you asymmetrically sample), then your results may be abnormally high or low for the average and therefore would regress back to the mean. Regression to the mean can also happen because you take a very small, unrepresentative sample (say, the highest 1 percent of the population or the lowest ten percent).

 Regression to the mean and co-relation

Whenever the correlation between two variable is imperfect, there will be regression to the mean.

Real life examples

The Sports Illustrated jinx is a good case in point of regression to the mean. The jinx states that whoever appears on the cover of SI is going to have a poor following year (or years). But the “jinx” is actually regression towards the mean. Most players have good games, and they have bad games. A winning streak is usually just that: a lucky streak. And it leads to being on the cover of SI. But it’s statistically likely to be followed by a fall back to average performance.

Our mind try to search for causality, ignoring the regression part

 Correction

Start with an estimate of the average (assuming there is no relation)
Determine the value that matches your impression of the evidence.
Obtain / Estimate the correlation .
If the correlation is .30, move 30% of the distance from the average to the matching impression.

Example

Relationship between the quality of the CEO and successful firms

 Correlation

A very generous estimate of the correlation between the success of the firm and the quality of its CEO might be as high as .30, indicating 30% overlap.

Your Impression of the evidence

In a well-ordered and predictable world, the correlation would be perfect, and the stronger CEO would be found to lead the more successful firm in 100%

 Average

If the relative success of similar firms was determined entirely by factors that the CEO does not control (call them luck, if you wish), you would find the more successful firm led by the weaker CEO 50% of the time.

Correction formula

Stronger CEO = AVG + (DISTANCE between impression and AVG) - correlation
Successful CEO = 50 + (100 -50) \* .3 = 50 + 15 = 65%

title: "Software Defined Data Center SDDC"
date: 2020-10-16T20:49:46+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["virtualization", "devops"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
What is software-defined data center?
The software-defined data center approach extends industry-leading virtualization beyond computing, network and storage, making data center services painless in terms of configuration and managing virtual machines.

The SDDC integrates those virtualization layers, creating a single, hyperconverged environment that facilitates IT resources delivery as a service — without regard to whether the SDDC is deployed in a private, public or hybrid cloud environment. A single management platform standardizes management across the virtualization layers and enables policy-based automation that simplifies operations.

 Software-defined data center components

Cloud Management Layer
Sevice Catalog: The Cloud Management layer comprises the service catalog that houses the facilities to be deployed. Catalog items are unique applications, infrastructure, or other services accessible in the catalog. 

 The orchestration offers the workflows to deploy catalog items; for example, you can give it a list of the servers' IPs,  with a base of hypervisor installed on them, and request a workload domain; from this point onwards, it will orchestrate and take care of all the components into it, therefore it will make sure all the hosts have the same hypervisor installed and deploy the software-defined networking, etc.
   
 a self-service portal that allows end-users to use the SDDC.

 Virtual Infrastructure Layer 

Decoupling resources from the physical layer,  additional processes, and technologies build on top of the infrastructure to bring forth infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and platform as a service (PaaS).

Hypervisor. 
Resource Pooling, when creating your clyster , you can create a virtual pool when you say how much resources individual logical groups, for example, if we have three different types of applications A, B, and C, you can say application A should have 50% of the resources we have and B, C 25% each so you can do that through resource pooling, or you can say first come first served.
Virtualization control.

Physical layers 
Compute.
Network, you need a physical network connected to the servers to access the servers and the virtual machines.
Storage, for example, block storage, file storage, and a variety of others.

 Business Continuity
Fault Tolerance: If you need to have an immediate failover, you still have to have a cluster solution, but you still enable individual virtual machines fault tolerance. By   having a standby copy of the same VM, so if the host that has the virtual machine fails, it  can switch automatically to the other VM.
   
Disaster recovery, so you can have a replication goes to another site. If one of the sites, the whole data center loses power, burns down, or even explodes, you can have a ready a secondary site where you have a constant replication; you can switch over.
   
Backup and restore: The general rule of having your backup in multiple locations, one of them should be offline, that what you supposed to have, one use case if you hit by cryptolocker, so if the datastore is encrypted and you have your back settings in the same site, there is a very high chance the backup will be affected as well.

Security 
Compliance, for example, if you are working in healthcare so your infrastructure should be compliant.

title: "Storage Media Types"
date: 2020-10-17T20:43:42+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["storage", "hardware"]
author: "M. Awad"
---

SAS VS SATA 

SAS and SATA are two technologies used to ferry instruction and data from the motherboard to a storage drive.

Before we proceed any further, it is important to know that SATA nor SAS isn't a storage drive per se. Instead, storage drives like SSD and HDD may be built with SATA or SAS connectors.

 SATA
SATA shines when data is being transferred into the storage drive. On the flip side, SATA doesn't work that well when it transfers data out of the storage drive.

SAS (Serial attached SCSI)
Severs typically support SAS (Serial attached SCSI) pronounced "scuzzy" or Serial Attached Small Computer System Interface, which provides higher performance than SATA in server environments.
 
You can have SAS in your PC; that being said,  you won't get as much performance because they optimized for server environments where multiple clients are accessing the disk simultaneously.

Again SAS is beyond media type and connection; it's architecture as well.

Unlike SATA, SAS has backward compatibility; your SAS drive bay, whether in your server or your storage system, can take SAS SSD, SAS HDD, SATA SSD, SATA HDD drives. It doesn't work the other way around, though.

 SDD vs. HDD 

SDD drives provide the highest performance, but that doesn't come cheap; SDD has the highest GB cost.

SATA HDD available in a larger size with a lower cost.

SAS HDD provides a happy medium between performance, capacity, and cost.

title: 'Substitute Easy Question for the Harder One'
date: 2020-07-26T20:46:49+01:00
draft: true
tags: ['']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

Subjects are shown a wheel of fortune. Unbeknownst to them, the wheel only stops on numbers 10 and 65. After the wheel is spun, subjects are asked a totally unrelated question: What is your best guess of the percentage of African nations in the UN? The average estimate of people who have just seen the number 10 is 25%. The average estimate of people who have just seen the number 65 is 45%. The answers are anchored by the previous information, even when there was no link between them.

In Kahneman’s new book, he writes, “When confronted with a problem — choosing a chess move or deciding whether to invest in stock — the machinery of intuitive thought does the best it can. If the individual has relevant expertise, she will recognize the solution, and the intuitive solution that comes to her mind is likely to be correct.” But when the question is difficult and a skilled solution is not available? We answer an easier and related question. If the question is “Should I invest in Ford Motor Company stock?” the easier question to answer is “Do I like Ford cars?”

Investing, playing chess, weighing a management dilemma — the processes are similar. “This is the essence of intuitive heuristics: when faced with a difficult question, we often answer an easier one instead, usually without noticing the substitution,” says Kahneman.

title: 'Taboo Trade Off'
date: 2020-09-08T23:23:34+01:00
draft: true
tags: ['Thinking Fallacies']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

The survey of parents’ reactions to a potentially hazardous insecticide mentioned earlier also included a question about the willingness to accept increased risk. The respondents were told to imagine that they used an insecticide where the risk of inhalation and child poisoning was 15 per 10,000 bottles. A less expensive insecticide was available, for which the risk rose from 15 to 16 per 10,000 bottles. The parents were asked for the discount that would induce them to switch to the less expensive (and less safe) product.

More than two-thirds of the parents in the survey responded that they would not purchase the new product at any price! They were evidently revolted by the very idea of trading the safety of their child for money.

The minority who found a discount they could accept demanded an amount that was significantly higher than the amount they were willing to pay for a far larger improvement in the safety of the product.

Anyone can understand and sympathize with the reluctance of parents to trade even a minute increase of risk to their child for money. It is worth noting, however, that this attitude is incoherent and potentially damaging to the safety of those we wish to protect. Even the most loving parents have finite resources of time and money to protect their child (the keeping-my-child-safe mental account has a limited budget), and it seems reasonable to deploy these resources in a way that puts them to best use.

Money that could be saved by accepting a minute increase in the risk of harm from a pesticide could certainly be put to better use in reducing the child’s exposure to other harms, perhaps by purchasing a safer car seat or covers for electric sockets.

sockets. The taboo tradeoff against accepting any increase in risk is not an efficient way to use the safety budget. In fact, the resistance may be motivated by a selfish fear of regret more than by a wish to optimize the child’s safety.

title: "Thick Provisioning vs Thin Provisioning"
date: 2020-10-19T19:33:39+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["storage", "virtualization"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
When you create a virtual machine, you have to elect storage, and you have two options, thick and thin, so what are thick provisioning and thin provisioning, and how they differ.

Thin Provisioning
Allocates storage as needed. It's cost-effective and mostly used for file/objects' storage; the S3 bucket is an example.

 Thick provisioning 
Thick storage allocates virtual storage at the time of the request, so let's say you decide you're going with two terabytes of storage, which means you will get all of the two terabytes at the time of creation. 

Of course, it’s quite likely that you will end up not using all of those two terabytes, so obviously it's not space-efficient, but on the upside, it gives a performance hit as the storage doesn't need to grow at the time you need to. Mostly used for creating virtual DAS, in AWS, it's used EBS volume. 

So why to go with think provisioning?

Before any blocks could be used, the blocks have to zero first, so if you are writing some data, the block that is being written to it has to have 0 in it, which can take a little time and consumes resources.

 Thick-provisioning Eager-zeroed
In the case of thin provisioning, the implications of that 0 initialization will delay the actual data being written to the block.

So, in the case of an intensive writing workload like SQL virtual machine or SharePoint, eager-zero thick provisioning is recommended.

One drawback of Eager-zeroed, though, it requires more time to delete all write the data at the time of the creation.

Thick-provisioning lazy-zeroed 
Like eager-zeroed lazy zeroed disk, it takes all of the space at creation time, but this space may still hold some old data. This old data will be deleted and zeroed as needed.

title: "Virtual Machine Files"
date: 2020-10-18T17:25:18+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["virtualization", "devops", "vmware"]
author: "M. Awad"
---
 Virtual machine itself consists of multiple files that reside on the data store itself.

Global virtual machine files.
.vmx : Virtual machine configuration file, the .vmx file stores all virtual machine settings you configure through the vSphere Web Client,  99% of the time, you don't need to edit this file manually.

.vswap: as soon as you create a new virtual machine, it will create a new file, so if you have memory contention in the environment, the system can remove the data into the swap, to free space of the main memory of the server.

.vnvram BIOS file contains the saved state of the BIOS of a virtual machine in a form similar to non-volatile memory. NVRAM file is  not subjected to power outages, so information is retained even when the computer is turned off; again, you don't need to mess with this file.

.log: log files, which is very useful in troubleshooting if you want to know, for example, what is happening in the boot process of the virtual machine

.vmtx:  .vmtx file is created when you convert a virtual machine to a template. The .vmtx file replaces the virtual machine configuration file (.vmx file). The extension's change makes sure the file is no longer treated as a .vmx file; therefore, typical virtual machine-specific tasks such as power-on or reset can no longer be executed against it.

.vmdk:The .vmdk file (also called the descriptor) is a text file that contains configuration information about a VM's virtual hard drive. The descriptor file also contains a reference to the large data (flat-vmdk) files as well as information on the virtual disks drive sectors, heads, cylinders and disk adapter type.

.flat-vmdk: The *-flat.vmdk file is the virtual equivalent of a physical hard drive; this is where raw data is written.

 Snapshot-related files

When a snapshot is taken, multiple new files are created in the VM folder. These include .vmdk, -sparse.vmdk, .vmsd, and .vmsn, as shown at the following screenshot

.vmdk: snapshot disk file
*.snapshot.vmsm
*.snapshot#.vmen memory content of the sanpshot 

Suspended-VM-related files
when you put the VM in suspend mode
.*vmss suspended file state
.*vmem suspended snapshot memory state

Because they are wired in series, so each battery's positive terminal is connected to the next battery's negative terminal, to meet the power need of teh device, when batteries are connected in a series, they're linked together such that the positive terminal of one battery is connected to the negative terminal of another.

The total voltage across batteries connected in series is equal to the sum of their individual voltages.

When a series of batteries is connected to a circuit, the same current will flow through all of the batteries,

Rather than every time you need to wrap an element or a group of elements, you create the element, cut and paste the inner tags, you may make use of a Wrap with Abbreviation a handy time-saver native feature of visual studio code

!--more--

Highlight the text text (optional)
Open command palette (usually ⌘ Command + Shift+ P)
Execute Emmet: Wrap with Abbreviation
Enter a tag div (or an abbreviation .wrapperp)
Hit Enter

You can create a keyboard shortcut for it to make it even better

Open Keyboard Shortcuts by typing ⌘ Command + K

Search for emmet wrap..

Click the plus sign to the left of "Emmet: Wrap with Abbreviation"

Type your short cut of choice .e.g ⌥ Option + W

Hit Enter

title: 'Working With Styles Wordpress'
date: 2020-08-01T21:28:06+01:00
draft: true
tags: ['wordpress']
author: 'M. Awad'
---

When you're creating your theme, you may be tempted to add your styles hardcoded to your templates

Enqueuing Styles

In your functions.php

wpenqueuestyle('style', getstylesheeturi())

style is just a unique name you cna name any thing else, wordpress uses it for depency and making sure

Loading external stylesheet

wpenqueuestyle('font-css', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Open+Sans|Varela+Round');

Dependency, say you need file to load before another fiule

wpenqueuestyle('style', getstylesheeturi(), ['font-css'] )

Version you cna leave it, but if you want to avaoid cahce while you're devolping you count on time

wpenqueuestyle('style', getstylesheeturi(), ['font-css'], getthetime());

it's common and good practice to group all of your registered styles under one function, and calling it when a specific event occurs, usually when the styles/scripts are enqueued

function mythemethemestyles() {
	wpenqueuestyle('font-css', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Open+Sans|Varela+Round');
	wpenqueuestyle('main-css', getstylesheeturi(), ['font-css'], getthetime());

}

addaction('wpenqueuescripts', 'mythemetheme_styles', 10);

wpenqueuescripts Fires when scripts and styles are enqueued, Despite the name, wpenqueuescripts function works for both.

title: "Turn your own handwriting as a font"
date: 2020-06-30T21:20:52+01:00
draft: false
tags: ["online-tools"]
---

Web site Calligraphr creates a computer font of your own handwriting. !--more--

Fill out in longhand the alphabet on a Calligraphr-provided template you print out.
Scan it in, make sure the file is at 150dpi to 300dpi.
Upload to the site and preview your custom font and give your font a name, then pick the output format of your choice, either .ttf or .otf.
Download it to your machine.
Install and start using your new-found font.
